ygData.subject: Self-adaptive Mutation Rates, Novelty Search and CMA-ES
ygData.msgSnippet: I started a new thread to distinguish this topic from the previous discussion. Self-adaptive mutation rates are a terrible idea: Jeff, thanks for pointing this

Subject: Self-adaptive Mutation Rates, Novelty Search and CMA-ES
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=434634266; y=0ut82VxU8jbRZk7ymN4Y8Gp54gT0QgZ_CSR2pXIPvXUC6VDnaurj2A

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8

I started a new thread to distinguish this topic from the previous
discussion.

Self-adaptive mutation rates are a terrible idea:
Jeff, thanks for pointing this out. That is an interesting paper! To be
honest I haven't read it before; so, you are saying that self-adaptive
mutation rates can be more effective on smoother fitness landscapes,
correct?

Novelty Search:
Joel, could novelty search be seen as a way of creating a smoother fitness
landscape? If yes, then based on what you said, is this the reason why
self-adaptive mutation rates work better when coupled with novelty search?


I believe the idea of self-adaptive mutation rates formed the basis for
more advanced evolution strategies such as CMA-ES. I am not trying to
defend CMA-ES here, which I agree with Jeff that it works differently than
the basic approach of encoding the mutation rates in the genotype. However,
I am wondering whether a combination of novelty search with CMA-ES would be
a good approach in speeding up the search for novel behaviours.

Of course, I can see some disadvantages of CMA-ES, an example being that
the genotype is a vector of real numbers with a fixed size... What do you
think?


Vassilis

--047d7bf0e4782bd17404f857c0ab
